title: Chapter 2 of advanced R problems discussion
description: A new article created using the Distill format.
contents:
```{r setup, include=FALSE} options(dplyr.print_max = 1e9) library(pacman) p_load(tibble, broom, snakecase, tidyr, data.table,colorout, conflicted, purrr,ztable, hrbrthemes,readr, dplyr, magrittr, lubridate, zoo, mi, survival, ggplot2, printr, lsmeans, ggthemes, knitr, xtable, doBy, nlme, reshape2, pander, pwr, tufte)
opts_chunk\(set(warning = F, message = F, echo=F, fig.width=3.2,  fig.height=3, results='asis', dev='pdf',  opts_chunk\)set(cache.path = “cache/”)) source(‘~/work/reports/templates/zz.tools.R’) options(scipen = 1, digits = 2) knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = FALSE) ```
Introduction
My most common usage of the todonotes package, is to insert an uncustomized todonotes somewhere in a latex document. An example of this usage is the command Sample reference section reference. (Pocock 2005).
Methods
A careful reading of the chapter. Reference additional references including:
Results
Notes and offered solutions.
References


Pocock, SJ. 2005. “when (not) to stop a clinical trial for Benefit.” JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association 294 (17): 2228–30. http://jama.ama-assn.org/content/294/17/2228.short.

title: unix tools for DS developers
description: A new article created using the Distill format.
contents:
Introduction This is the first of hopefully a number of posts
describing the setup of a number of essential tools for working with data.table in a unix environment. My most common usage of the todonotes package, is to insert an uncustomized todonotes somewhere in a latex document. An example of this usage is the command Sample reference section reference. (Pocock 2005).
Methods
A careful reading of the chapter. Reference additional references including:
Results
Notes and offered solutions.
References
Distill is a publication format for scientific and technical writing, native to the web.
Learn more about using Distill at https://rstudio.github.io/distill.



Pocock, SJ. 2005. “when (not) to stop a clinical trial for Benefit.” JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association 294 (17): 2228–30. http://jama.ama-assn.org/content/294/17/2228.short.

title: programming ggplot timeseries function options
description: A chronicle of the evolution of a ggplot programming exploration.
contents:
Introduction
Programming with ggplot or tidyverse tools has been a challenge for me until recently. After reading a number of blog posts and the chapter on tidyverse programming in Wickham’s Advanced R text (Wickham 2014) I have a better idea of how to build the ggplot call.
Methods





# Get quantmod

start <- as.Date("2019-01-01")
end <- as.Date("2019-12-31")
#getSymbols(c("TSLA", "GOOG"), src = "yahoo", from = start, to = end)
#tesla2019  = TSLA[,"TSLA.Close"] %>%  as.data.frame %>%
    #rownames_to_column(var="date") %>%  
    #data.frame(stock="tesla",.) %>%  
    #setNames(c("stock", "date", "value"))
#dat1  = GOOG[,"GOOG.Close"]%>%  as.data.frame %>%  
    #rownames_to_column(var="date") %>%  
    #data.frame(stock="google",.) %>%  
    #setNames(c("stock", "date", "value")) %>%  
       #rbind(tesla2019)     %>% 
      #mut(date = ymd(date)) 
write_csv(dat1, "stocks_time_series.csv")
dat1 = read_csv("stocks_time_series.csv")

explore = function(data, stocks, xlim=NULL, ylim=NULL){
stocks = enquo(stocks)
xlim = enquo(xlim)
ylim = enquo(ylim)
#rids = !!rids[!!rids %in% unique(data$rid)]
dat1 = data  %>% fil(stock %in% !! stocks  ) 
stocks = dat1 %>%  pull(stock) %>%  unique
browser()
dat2 = tibble(stock=c("tesla","google"), start=start, end=end)
gg=    ggplot()+
geom_rect(data=dat2, mapping=aes(xmin=start, xmax=start+90,ymin=-Inf, 
      ymax=Inf), alpha=0.5,fill="grey85")+
geom_rect(data=dat2, mapping=aes(xmin=start+120, xmax=start+210,ymin=-Inf, 
      ymax=Inf), alpha=0.5,fill="grey85")+
    geom_vline(data=dat2, xintercept=start, 
           linetype="dotted", colour="black", alpha=.25) +
    geom_vline(data=dat2, xintercept=start+60, 
           linetype="dotted", colour="black", alpha=.25) +
    geom_vline(data=dat2, aes(xintercept=start+90), 
           linetype="dotted", colour="black", alpha=.25) +
    geom_vline(data=dat2, aes(xintercept=start+120), 
           linetype="dotted", colour="black", alpha=.25) +
    geom_hline(data=dat2, yintercept=250, size = .2, 
           linetype="solid", colour="red", alpha=.5) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800")) + xlab("date")+
    facet_wrap( ~ stock)+theme_bw() +
geom_line(data=dat1, aes(x = date, y = value), size=.2)  +
theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90,hjust = 0, vjust = .5))+
theme(legend.position="bottom")+
  scale_color_manual(values = c("#00AFBB", "#E7B800")) +
theme(strip.background = element_blank(),
   strip.text.y = element_blank())
gg
}
gg = dat1 %>% explore(stocks = c("tesla","google"))
Called from: explore(., stocks = c(“tesla”, “google”))

gg


#works but how to set ylim and xlim, and the size of the red horiz
#line.
